pros: Pros: - Work/life balance. - Friendly & diverse staff. - Meaningful work with staff members who believe in the organization's mission. - Benefits package.
cons: None. Its been a great experience.

pros: Is a good place to work
cons: No cons to report on this

pros: The only good thing is what you can see written on paper.
cons: An organization with a mission to make change in the world yet lacks serious fundamental values to be the change within themselves. Extremely poor leadership across all departments, big egos, no appreciation for the mid and junior staff that make all their achievements possible. Highly suggest any other place.

review_title: Mission driven work with a great team
pros: Mission driven and impactful work, opportunities for growth

job_title: Communications Manager in New York, NY
pros:
The people are really great and are like-minded. 
Remote-first.
cons: No opportunities for growth. Promotions are granted to favorites. If you give critical feedback you are met with retribution. Unfair compensation and not a great work-life balance. All of the Senior leaders are friends, and there is no accountability for them.

review_title: Not a place for young professionals with hopes of professional growth
pros: Very nice, intelligent people with a fantastic vision for what the organization could be, strong political connections to powerful individuals. Looks good on a resume.
cons:
Everyone at the top has an ego and the damage that it reaps is mostly on junior staff. No matter how hard you work or how much skill you exhibit, I observed that most people will not recognize it, reward it or seek to utilize it in a responsible way. Most junior staff don’t get promoted over time when they should, yet are expected to assume greater and greater responsibility over areas which they should not be expected to. Senior staff has tunnel vision that neglects the needs of their subordinates and only focuses on the mission, which over time times causes toxic workplace behavior at all levels. If you’re already pretty senior in your profession and/or have Obama connections, there may be value here for you at this organization. If you’re a young professional looking and hoping to grow and be given trust/valuable experience in an important space, I would look elsewhere. 

Also, for a progressive organization, they operate like it’s 2012 and they’re still in the Obama WH. Old habits die hard, but I think it’s pretty clear that the way an administration runs and the way a non-profit runs are very much not the same.

pros: An awesome organization to work on some of the most important issues in the U.S. Everyone is really nice and I liked the benefits.
cons: Honestly, none. I enjoyed my time there.

pros: Pretty happy with my time here so far, fair compensation for the most part
cons: Disorganized executives, plus lack of annual bonuses
None that I can think of!
under transition, big organization that is doing a lot- can become easily overwhelming

pros: Lots of nice people trying to do good
cons: Big egos. Insecure management. Felt toxic.

pros: Good people fighting for important causes. Pay for health care.
cons: Start up so at this point most of the staff are former Obama White House, government, campaign staff who lack business experience in the nonprofit world = challenges around sustainability.

pros: People are passionate, good causes, nice office location
cons: Underpaid, disorganized, workspace layout is not good, toxic masculinity coming from some of the males, you will not get a chance to work with or learn from everyone except your team

pros: People are friendly, they pay for health benefits.
cons: Civic Nation is a failing experiment. They don't have the senior management in place that they need, they never did, and structural problems have set in. High profile campaigns like "Better Make Room" have left.

pros: Great work being done and friendly environment.
Several very nice colleagues that were a pleasure to see every day.
cons: Everything. This is not a nonprofit, it's a fiasco.
